awd_titl_txt: Complex Plasma under Microgravity:   Utilizing the International Space Station Plasma Krystal-4 Facility and Beyond
awd_abstract_narration:
This award will support the analysis of data and a series of dedicated experiments on the International Space Station (ISS) aimed at understanding fundamental properties of the complex plasma systems.  Plasmas have long been studied in the astrophysical setting since most of the universe is in a plasma state and are important in explaining the live cycles of stars. The heavy use of plasma production methods in the semiconductor industry also demonstrates the economic importance of plasma based production methods in our society. In nearly all situations were plasmas exist, small particles may be embedded in the plasma environment either as a natural component, as a result of unintended growth from chemical reactions, or introduced intentionally. The presence of the dust particle component can significantly change the overall behavior and the properties of the plasma. In some cases, the presence of the dust can have negative effects such as significant yield reductions in processing plasma manufacturing or undesired complications in the design of fusion devices. On the other hand, the presence of the dust can also result in new plasma production methods and provides an accessible, excellent model system to investigate the universal behavior and properties of general complex particle systems. The full potential of the complex plasma research requires that some experiments be performed under reduced gravitational influence, as provided by the ISS. This award will support the training of the next generation of highly qualified scientists and engineers by providing the opportunity to work with a team of international collaborators.

The investigators will make use of the recently developed microgravity complex (dusty-) plasma facility Plasma Krystal-4 (PK-4), which is a European-Russian apparatus now on the International Space Station. Working in a close collaboration with the European core team of PK-4 scientists, the US team will study fundamental aspects of complex plasma including the charging and interaction of individual particles, particle transport and the thermal properties of the overall system. These fundamental interactions between the particles in a complex plasma is the basis for understanding its overall behavior. For example, increasing the strength of the interaction relative to the random motion can cause the system to undergo a transition from an irregular, uncorrelated (liquid) state to an ordered, crystalline structure (solid). Using experimental data obtained from the PK-4 experiment, the charging and particle pair interaction will be studied by examining the dynamics of individual particles during pair collisions. Particle transport and heating of particles will be examined using additional experimental data obtained from the PK-4 experiment and results from dedicated ground based experiments. Required software tools to follow the motion of individual particles (particle tracking velocimetry) and the overall particle flow (particle image velocimetry) will be developed. A series of experiments to support the development of potential future microgravity complex plasma experiments will also be performed.  This award to support an undergraduate student is made under a "NASA/NSF Partnership on Science of Dusty Plasmas: Utilizing the PK-4 Facility on board the International Space Station" and is complementary to a NASA award made under the joint program.

por.por_cntn:
The project "Complex Plasma under Microgravity, Utilizing the International Space Station Experiment 'PK-4' and Beyond" is dedicated to fundamental complex/dusty plasma research. Activities have been supported by a partnership between NASA and NSF. The results reported here reflect specifically the support granted by NSF, namely the involvement of undergraduate students in the project at Auburn University.

Within the project we have made use of ESA's International Space Station (ISS) complex plasma experiment facility "PK-4", its ground-based setup located at the German Aerospace Center (DLR e.V.) as well as local laboratory-based dusty plasma experiments at Auburn University and Wittenberg University. During the course of the project we established a deep collaboration with Baylor University, Giessen University and the German Aerospace Center. The latter two are located in Germany. Within the scope of this project we have performed experiments, applied analytical and numerical analysis techniques, and developed new analysis, diagnostic and operational tools to study complex plasma.

The NSF grant was used to support the activities of four undergraduate students from the disciplines of electronic engineering, aerospace engineering and physics. We would have liked to support more students but due to Covid restrictions the number of available candidates was limited.

From the four students, one developed a Langmuir probe plasma diagnostic system for our laboratory activities. This allowed a project graduate student to have access to an additional reference measurement for his goal: to develop a novel plasma diagnostic for complex plasma. A second undergraduate student participated in a plasma crash-course taught by the PI and helped to develop a theory to describe the impedance of a plasma for our specific experimental constraints. A third student analyzed the dynamics of the particles in dusty plasma experiments performed with the "Plasmakristall-4" (PK-4) experiment aboard the ISS, as well as related, preparatory experiments utilizing the corresponding ground-based facility. Topics of interest in these specific experiments was the change in particle temperature and the energy transport as a result of an instant change in the particle interaction initiated by a user-controlled modification in the plasma background. The fourth student developed a new image analysis technique to identify and analyze regular-structure occurrences during a phase transition from liquid to solid in a dusty plasma experiment. In the specific experiment, a complex plasma (initially in a liquid state) was compressed until the system went through a phase transition to finally show ordered, crystalline structures. The work of this student is continuing and is expected to find its application as a control tool for the next-generation space experiment facility, as well as a new analysis technique for our future laboratory activities.

Overall, the students' activities were very successful. In most cases they had the opportunity to present their results at the annual meeting of the Division of Plasma Physics of the American Physical Society (APS-DPP). The undergraduate students were further involved in the planing of the ISS-based experiments and thus had the opportunity to experience research performed at the level of a broad international collaboration.

While the NSF part of the project ends with this report, we continue our work on fundamental complex plasma behavior supported by NASA/JPL. The ongoing, expanded project includes activities to define and realize the next-generation complex plasma space experiment, "COMPACT", for the ISS. One of the recent undergraduate students supported by the NSF grant joined us in this mission now as graduate student. Due to the combined NASA/JPL/NSF support, our team could establish a leading role in the international microgravity complex plasma activities.

We would like to deeply thank NSF for their strong support in our research activities.
